title: The Iconic Empire State Building Lights Up In Orange, As Indians In New York Celebrate Diwali

The Iconic Empire State Building Lights Up In Orange, As Indians In New York Celebrate Diwali

The Iconic Empire State Building Lights Up In Orange, As Indians In New York Celebrate Diwali

Diwali is a festival that is not only celebrated in India, but also by Indians who live abroad. Recently, the iconic Empire State Building in New York was lit up in orange colour, in a ceremony to celebrate Diwali. It was led by an organisation for Indian diaspora.

The structure turned orange as Indians in New York celebrated Diwali. You might be wondering who lit up the monument. Well, it was the Federation of Indian Associations (FIA) - the largest non-profit umbrella organisation of Indian community in the tri-state area of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

The Empire State Building lit up in its full glory this weekend in celebration of Diwali pic.twitter.com/Q4VJk5wqsb — Sid Nag 🇺🇸☁️🏃🏻‍♂️🎤🎸⛷🏌🏾‍♂️ (@sidnewyork) October 27, 2019

The special ceremony was organised by FIA with the Empire State Realty Trust. The ceremony was attended by FIA Chairman Ramesh Patel, President Alok Kumar, Trustee Ankur Vaidya, and Past President Srujal Parikh and singer and songwriter Arjun Coomaraswamy.

There were dance and music performances too. "The tower lit up with millions of festive lights in Orange, the colour of the Diya or the lamp and cast a beautiful hue across the night sky of New York City spreading the message of oneness in celebrating the victory of good over evil," FIA said.

Last year also, the iconic building was lit up in orange to celebrate Diwali. The building is also illuminated in tri-colour (Saffron, White and Green) every August to celebrate the Indian Independence Day!
